Can't open file with unknown extension in remote directory.

note.body:
This looks like Builder is actually doing the right thing to protect itself.

Locally, Builder can know this is a `application/x-zerosize` or `text/plain` (or inherits from `text/plain`).

When I `gio info 'sftp://server/file.ec'` I get `application/octet-stream` which we refuse to open as it could break the text editor if it were something like an executable.

I think if their is a correct fix for this it probably should not be in Builder because we absolutely have to protect against non-text files getting open with GtkTextView, given it's performance characteristics.

Someone could introduce a dialog to ask the user for input and I'd review a MR for that (but wont write it myself).

note.body:
```
error: Requested extension org.freedesktop.Sdk.Extension.llvm18/x86_64/master not installed
```

There is no `master`, it's just our last ditch effort to guess what SDK extension is needed. It's terribly complicated in that we have to find the common ancestor from your SDK (in this case `org.gnome.Sdk//master`) and any version of `org.freedesktop.Sdk.Extension.llvm18`.

In this case, for installing, we discovered that both inherit from `org.freedesktop.Sdk//24.08` so that is the version we need to download.

However, when flatpak-builder runs, it doesn't find enough info and bails with it's best guess, which is the same branch as your SDK triplet.

What 47.2 was supposed to fix, was locating the installation of these if they landed in our private Builder installation (in `~/Projects/.gnome-builder/flatpak/repo/`).

Here things are building both from jhbuild and Nightly. Stable appears to work to.

target_title: libide/gui: fix preference window reuse

note.body:
This would break how they work with regards to window groups by project. We do allow opening the preferences multiple times, so they can be transient for to the project they were opened with. Particularly if those are on different workspaces.

We only add the window to the application specifically to hold the application alive for `gnome-builder --preferences`.

It is all even more complicated by both app preferences and project preferences being IdeTweaksWindow.

What we probably need to do is iterate the workspaces (which themselves are a window group) for an existing preferences window.

note.body:
Nothing has changed here in ages from Builder or GtkSourceView, so this has to be one of two things:

 * GTK (or other font related bits below it such as Pango)
 * Your font (`fc-match monospace` will tell you what Monospace is if that is your current setting)
 * Something in editorconfig/etc is somehow causing 0-width tabs (though I don't think this can even happen given the property value ranges)

If you open the GTK inspector, select the source view, then click on the buffer property, the buffer should have a file-settings. Go to view that and you'll see something like this with the compiled values of settings.

target_title: Unable to develop and run OBS Studio Flatpak since version 47

note.body:
The issue still remain on GNOME Builder for giving CMake a bad value to `CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR`, this variable should have a value that will be prefixed with `CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX` (`/app` as `/app/`).

Many `CMAKE_INSTALL_` value are meant to be prefixed by `CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX`, this a CMake behavior that OBS CMake depends on and standalone flatpak-builder does not break it.

GNOME Builder enforce a behavior change on CMake which can break some complex CMake buildsystem that relies on CMake default behavior.

```
ide_config_replace_config_opt (config, "-DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR:PATH", "/app/lib");
```

should have been:
```
ide_config_replace_config_opt (config, "-DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR:PATH", "lib");
```
which ends up being `/app/lib` or `lib` and not only the former.

note.body:
As an olive branch to make things a bit easier on OBS, with commit 8cda9d3762609a36ad9ec4cce04880df44a4f5a9 in place, all you'll need to do in your manifest is:

```patch
diff --git a/build-aux/com.obsproject.Studio.json b/build-aux/com.obsproject.Studio.json
index fb32fd292..21b33446e 100644
--- a/build-aux/com.obsproject.Studio.json
+++ b/build-aux/com.obsproject.Studio.json
@@ -74,6 +74,7 @@
             "builddir": true,
             "config-opts": [
                 "-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo",
+                "-DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR:PATH=lib",
                 "-DOBS_CMAKE_VERSION=3",
                 "-DENABLE_WAYLAND=ON",
                 "-DENABLE_BROWSER=ON",
```

And then builder will not force the override to what Flatpak used to internally patch cmake implicitly use.

note.body:
Okay, I'm going to close this issue from the Builder side because I consider obs usage of `os_get_executable_path_ptr()` unable to handle any cmake configuration which uses absolute paths, and that seems pretty fundamentally broken. There is no guarantee that cmake configuration paths are relative only and therefore this would break just as much if it were `/usr/lib`.

It probably needs to be abstracted in such a way to handle relative paths (presumably for windows?) and absolute paths, but I don't think this is something we want to handle from Builder.

note.body:
Okay, there are (I think) only two possible code-paths that could match this.

The first is the semantic highlighter, the other is libspelling.

Can you try disabling the semantic highlighter and see if the crash goes away?

```
gnome-builder --preferences
```

Then go to `Text Editor` -> `Fonts & Styling` -> `Highlighting` and toggle the `Semantic Highlighting` box. You _might_ need to restart, but I don't think so.

target_title: Crash when saving

note.body: Just run `thread apply all bt` when you get the crash and are left at `gdb)` prompt.

target_title: Crash when saving

note.body: Also the dump appears to be missing the actual stack trace which is what we need. I need to know what modules we went through getting to that assertion failure.

target_title: Crash when saving

note.body: From the git perspective, I thought maybe https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-builder/-/issues/2253 could be related but that should already be in 47.1 (along with fixes in libspelling 0.4.1).

@chergert for some reason am failing to unblock myself on this
```
error: org.gnome.Sdk/x86_64/46 not installed
Failed to init: Unable to find sdk org.gnome.Sdk version master
```

I have installed all stable SDKs but they get to the machine but not accessible to gnome builder 
any known walk around ?

target_title: Crash when saving

note.body:
Yes, this is still happening with Flathub versions. I also built from main, but it still crashes.

While at it though, I tried deleting different files inside the project. After deleting the `HEAD` file inside `.git` directory, Builder would save the file with no issues. I couldn't reproduce the bug since.

note.body: Have you been able to reproduce this in the past couple days? I put out an update with newer libspelling version (0.4.2) a few days ago.

target_title: Use AdwSpinner
warning: internationalized messages should not contain the escape sequence

note.body: Easy newcomer task for someone wanting to work on things. Just remove the `\r\n` and make it happen in a second `feed()` call.

target_title: warning: internationalized messages should not contain the escape sequence
container error message closes immediately, can't read it

note.body: Yes, I understand that. I was more thinking about having a little button with 'i' icon next to the Build Environment dropdown to show what parameters should be used to successfully integrate it with Builder. Of course only when user selects Podman container, since Builder can see if the container is toolbx (it changes runner icon according to it).

Error tooltip quickly disappears when hovering over it

note.body:
Okay, I have some extra information about this issue.  
There seem to be two fundamental problems related to tooltip positioning and activation; This can also explain the inconsistent behaviour.

Example 1:  
![Inconsistent Tooltip Positioning](/uploads/7ad8919035c4504ffa85dc5b0f928d3b/Screencast_From_2024-10-05_15-33-05.webm)  
As can be seen here, the tooltip for the first argument to the function isn't positioned correctly; this means that, when the cursor position is updated, as it is no longer within the bounds of the text or the tooltip, the tooltip disappears.  
This can be reproduced for any first input of a function, although it is sometimes less problematic if the tooltip is still large enough to present itself above the text.

Example 2:  
![Unscaling Tooltip Activation](/uploads/ab5a8d754e35350d3d3e6e3780245701/Screencast_From_2024-10-05_15-38-00.webm)  
The second issue is that the area that can activate the tooltip scales with text size while the area that keeps the tooltip active doesn't. This is particularly evident at higher zoom levels as the original area to keep it active is small and to the top of the text. Even at regular zoom levels, these two areas do not coincide, as can be seen from the last part of the example.

To make both examples clearer, when the cursor is properly within the area that keeps the tooltip active, the cursor resets to the default state, while it otherwise remains the same as when hovering over regular text.  

Correct:  
![image](/uploads/9c84b2f4f713a06a4d9d74dfea5a1ed0/image.png)  
Incorrect:  
![image](/uploads/2080e67231427306d88528f4cced1693/image.png)

As far as my understanding goes, the first problem could be fixed on GNOME Builder's end, but the second one looks more likely related to GTK itself and the widgetry used.
  
It would be useful to see if anyone can reproduce these two issues (I'm not sure how different programming languages are handled yet, the example shown is in Rust) and, especially, if someone with deeper knowledge around GTK could look into the second one.

_A temporary workaround for the second issue could be resetting the zoom level, or even zooming out a bit to account for the area differences, while changing the font size to a greater value. While I have not tested this, if the hypothesis is correct then it should improve this case._

note.body:
After you've changed code in the Builder project, you can just click Run again and it will run your changes.

If you need a debugger, the menu next to the run button has a "Run with Debugger" entry which will start you changes to Builder inside a debugger.

target_title: Renamed files don't show their new name until their folder is closed and reopened

note.body:
I have seen this recently but haven't tracked it down.

If someone has the cycles to do so, I would start with running `gnome-builder -vvvv` with a nightly/devel build so you get tracing information about what is happening.

The first thing to look for is that we got an event about the change. After that make sure that it didn't get filtered out by the VCS (git/etc) filters. Then after that see why it did or didn't land in the target GListModel.
